paper minis forever and welcome back to another episode of black magic crafts

entirely 100% relates to miniatures little while ago I picked up some Reaper
bones minis of just some commoners bartenders bar wenches whatever just
stuff to use in town situations and when I base them I didn't want to put them on
like a rocky sandy grassy kind of base I wanted them to have like a tavern floor
like a wood plank floor and this is something that I see all the time on
minis and I think it looks great I know that there's a bunch of different ways
you can do this and I know that using green stuff to sculpt planks or use like
a textured rolling pin is a fantastic way to do it I know you can do it with
air dried clay but I didn't have any green stuff or clay so I had to just
make do with what I had so I turn to the obvious solution which was real wood
that presented a whole bunch of challenges of how to actually make real
wood planks on the little round base that looked good but I'm really happy
with the way it turned out and I'm thinking that you guys might be able to
benefit from seeing how I did it and maybe you can do that yourself or you
can transfer some of those ideas to other projects so this is a pretty quick
little tutorial this week let's jump over to the workbench and I'll show you
how I made these bases so start you're obviously going to need some sort of
mini base to work off of it doesn't matter what kind just your whatever you
use normally will do and you are going to need some sort of wood now you may be
tempted to go for a popsicle stick because that's something most of us
crafters have on hand but I elected to choose these copy of stir sticks instead
and I did that for two reasons one I think the width of these is a much
better scale for minis but also the wood tends to be thinner which is
going to make it a lot easier to work with in this application than the
popsicle sticks so the first thing I want to do is to take a sharp exacto
knife and kind of bevel and chamfer the edge of the stir stick just to give it
that you know Hume wood look you don't want this to be even you
don't want this to be straight you want it to change and look like it was carved
a long time ago it's the most efficient if you just do the entire length in one
go rather than cutting up your length and then trying to do it this is a lot
easier so that's that it's got a nice bevel on the edges and now we're going
to cut this into sections that are longer than your base is wide so you
know say like an inch and a quarter we're going to fly all over your work
area and you're gonna have to collect them later and this is what I like about
these coffee stir sticks versus popsicle sticks is that you can actually just cut
them with regular scissors you don't need to use side cutters or anything
like that so once you have your planks ready to go and your mini base just take
some regular super glue and completely cover the base with a nice puddle of
glue and working from one side just drop the planks across and make sure you are
hanging over the edge I mean you have cut these longer than the piece then the
base is wide so you want that overhanging each way but make sure when
you start on this edge is also overhanging the real only real challenge
here is not gluing your fingers to the base now to insure that these are really
really well bonded and aren't going to break off in the next steps I'm going to
take the superglue and I'm going to squirt it down the seams
and this is going to bond each of the pieces together as well as bonding it to
the base so it's going to be really really really strong now you got to give
this some time to set up so that your fingers don't stick to it in this next
step but as you can see here you have the planks overhanging all the edges and
we need to trim that excess off and I'm just going to use some scissors to get
it close just cut off little chunks at a time until you get the wood planks
almost flush with the mini base now you're left with a weird shape you know
that kind of looks like an octagon rather than a circle and here is the
biggest challenge of this method finding a way to get a nice round cut all the
way around I don't think there's a way to do it ahead of time and then glue the
pieces on I think that you need to do it this way where you overhang and then you
work this down until it's a nice circle if you have another method feel free to
drop me you know comment below to tell me what it is but this is the way that I
came up with with what was sitting on my desk I grabbed my rocks on rotary tool
this is the 50e it's a variable speed rotary tool it's
essentially the same as a dremel if you want to pick one of these up you can
check out the link in the description keeping in mind that you do need a power
supply for this the transformer but the good thing is that whatever power supply
you buy from procs on it's the same one that you can use on all their other
handheld tools like the handheld hot wire cutter so if it's a system you're
buying into you're only buying transformer once that being said you can
accomplish this with any similar rotary tool you know a lot of you probably have
Dremel tools kicking around they're all essentially the same I'm just using this
one because pr√≥ximos nice enough to give me one and I'm going to use like a drum
sanding bit on the end of this I'm going to turn it on and I'm just going to sand
away the excess until it is right flush with the base trying not to chew up the
plastic mini base too much in the process
and you can see because this mini bass
is a little bit tapered out its wider on the bottom in the top I'm using the tool
from the topside and kind of trying to follow that same angle so it looks like
it blends in I'm sure that it would be possible to do this the old-fashioned
way just with some sandpaper on a block if you don't have a dremel or something
similar it's just going to take longer now you're left with a nice wood plank
circle on your mini base and you now have an excellent surface to attach your
minis to when I was working on mine I actually cut off the little bit of
plastic molded base that came on the Reaper bones minis so that it was down
just to their feet so that I didn't have some weird mound on the wood and having
the solid wood base gave me a perfect material to both glue to but as well as
pin through I used the same dremel tool to drill a very small hole in the base
and send a pin up through the minis feet making them nice and strong so that's
all you need to do attach your mini and paint as usual
